Graphical abstract MOFs and MXenes, owing to their unique characteristics, are promising for advanced energy storage materials. This review explores recent developments, limitations, and future directions in MOF/MXene-based energy storage systems. The scalable integration of two-dimensional (2D) lamellar nanomaterials into flexible films opens up innovative possibilities for enhancing the performance and functionality of energy storage devices. However, a significant challenge lies in balancing mechanical strength with optimal energy storage properties. Achieving the necessary flexibility while maintaining high energy density and durability is complex due to the inherent trade-off between these properties. To address this issue and improve the overall performance of such nanomaterial films, researchers are exploring novel approaches such as hybridization with other materials, optimization of layer structures, and innovative fabrication techniques. In this vein, the emergence of hybrid nanomaterials composed of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and 2D MXene sheets offers exciting opportunities in the development of advanced materials for diverse applications. These MOF/MXene hybrid architectures exhibit a unique synergy that combines the exceptional surface area and tunable porosity of MOFs with the high electrical conductivity and mechanical strength of MXenes. This integration leads to the creation of versatile, multifunctional materials with promising capabilities in electrochemical energy storage and conversion, as well as environmental remediation. Hence, the present review delves into the various synthesis techniques employed to produce MOF/MXene hybrids, along with their diverse morphologies and properties, and examines the latest advancements in tailoring these nanoarchitectures for enhanced performance and efficiency. Additionally, the challenges and opportunities for future research are discussed in order to highlight the potential of these hybrid materials in pushing the boundaries of technological innovation across multiple scientific disciplines. Keywords Metal-organic framework Ti3C2T x MXene Hybridization Surface area Energy storage 1 Introduction In the dynamic and rapidly progressing field of materials science, the continuous pursuit of advanced materials with superior properties and unique application potentials has been a key driver of numerous breakthroughs [1]. Hybrid structures, which combine the characteristics of two or more materials, have become a central focus due to their versatility and diverse functionalities. Among these, the combination of MXenes and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has gained considerable attention, emerging as a promising area of research with increasing global interest [2,3]. MXenes, a class of 2D transition metal carbides and nitrides, are distinguished by their diverse structural motifs, rich surface chemistry, and interesting physicochemical properties [4–10]. The discovery of the first MXene, Ti3C2T x , at Drexel University in 2011 marked a significant advancement in materials science, occurring in the absence of prior stability predictions for such two-dimensional (2D) materials [11]. Since this initial discovery, over 30 different MXene compositions have been synthesized experimentally, and a considerable number of additional compositions have been theoretically predicted. Generally, the usual formula for MXenes is represented by the formula M n +1X n T X , where 'M' indicates early transition metals (Ti, Cr, Sc, V, Nb, Mo, Sc, Ti, Zr, Ta, etc.). Thus, 'X' element may consist of carbon, nitrogen, or a combination of both, while 'T X ' represents surface terminations (–F, –, –OH, –Cl). The parameter 'n' typically varies from 1 to 4. Their corresponding 3D phases are termed MAX phases (or M n +1AX n ), where “A” representing elements from groups IIIA to VIA. To date, the majority of MXenes have been synthesized through the selective removal of the “A” layers from MAX phases, typically achieved using hydrofluoric acid (HF) or a combination of lithium fluoride and hydrochloric acid [12–21]. In addition to their compositional flexibility and structural variety, MXene materials have been investigated for a broad range of applications owing to their diverse properties, including high electrical and thermal conductivity, biocompatibility, excellent chemical stability, efficient light absorption, and hydrophilicity [22–24]. Notably, MXenes have attracted significant interest in energy conversion applications, particularly in ion transport and salinity gradient energy harvesting, due to their high surface charge density, exceptional hydrophilicity, and ultrathin profiles which enable efficient ion permeability [25–33]. However, the quest to maximize the performance of MXene-based materials requires a delicate balance between capability and selectivity. While the short ion transport pathways provided by ultrathin MXene layers enhance the permeability, they may also decrease the selectivity by limiting the interactions with binding sites within the architecture channels [34–36]. This trade-off poses a significant challenge, as enhancing the ion selectivity by the incorporation of a 2D composite material often leads to reduced permeability [37]. As a result, innovative strategies must be developed to fine-tune the MXene properties in order to achieve optimal energy conversion performance while maintaining high levels of ion selectivity and permeability [38]. On the other hand, the MXene is establishing itself as a highly promising material for applications in electrochemical energy storage, including batteries and supercapacitors due to its distinctive combination of physical and chemical properties. Its superior performance is primarily attributed to its pseudocapacitive charge storage mechanism, complemented by electric double-layer characteristics, which together enhance the energy storage capabilities of the supercapacitor [39–41]. Notably, the extraordinary potential of the MXene extends beyond traditional energy storage systems. Its controlled interlayer spacing and unique chemical composition facilitate the development of next-generation technologies such as micro-supercapacitors [42–45], hybrid capacitors [46–48], and advanced batteries [49]. These innovative devices capitalize on the ability of the MXene to deliver high capacity and rapid charge-discharge cycles [50]. Such advancements represent a crucial evolution in the field, allowing these systems to achieve higher energy densities and store greater quantities of energy through hybridization and material engineering. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a unique class of porous crystalline hybrid materials (also named as porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or porous coordination networks (PCNs)). They consist of metal ions or clusters intricately coordinated to organic ligands. MOFs offer flexibility in design, allowing for the creation of diverse architectural structures tailored for specific purposes. These structures are at the forefront of modern materials science due to their remarkable versatility and tunable properties [51–54]. By integrating metallic nodes with organic linkers, the MOFs form an extensive class of 2D nanomaterials that can adopt a variety of morphologies, including nanoscale particles, lamellar structures, and polyhedrons [55–58]. As a concise and effective introduction to this field, the remarkable research findings pertaining to the design and synthesis of MOF-based materials are summarized in Fig. 1 . The design process encompasses the various stages involved in the formation, modification, and functionalization of these nanoparticles, in order to provide the MOFs with structural adaptability. This, in turn, grants the MOFs unique advantages in fields such as energy storage [59–64], catalysis [65–70], and gas separation [71–77], as they can be customized to optimize their performance for specific applications [78–85]. Despite their potential, the practical applications of MOFs are limited by their poor dispersibility in organic phases and their insufficient long-term stability [86–88]. To overcome these challenges, innovative approaches such as the development of new synthesis methods [52,89,90], surface modifications, and combinations with other materials [91–94], are essential for unlocking the full potential of the MOFs. These advances could lead to significant breakthroughs in sustainable technology, including more efficient energy storage systems and cleaner industrial processes. In this context, the convergence of 2D nanomaterials, specifically MOFs and MXenes, has opened up a new frontier in materials science with the potential to address many challenges in various technologies [95–99]. These materials share a common challenge of agglomeration between adjacent layers, which can hinder their performance [100,101]. However, researchers are addressing this limitation via innovative approaches such as optimizing the layer structures, utilizing advanced fabrication techniques, and creating hybrid nanomaterials [102,103]. The fusion of MOFs and MXene has given rise to hybrid architectures that leverage both the exceptional surface area and tunable porosity of the MOFs and the high electrical conductivity and mechanical strength of the MXenes [104–106]. The wide range of metal centers and organic linkers in MOF structures allow a broad choice of metal ions and organic linkers, offering tunability in terms of functionality. In contrast, other MXene composites, like MXene/polymer or MXene/carbon composites, may not offer as much flexibility in customizing the chemical properties for specific applications. In addition, given that the surface of MXene is prone to oxidation, leading to structural degradation and reduced electrochemical performance, efforts to mitigate this effect have focused on chemical interactions between organic molecules and MXene surface functional groups [107]. In this regard, Wu et al. developed V2CT x MXene as a metal source for synthesizing MOF nanosheets [108]. The high electronegativity of surface atoms on MXene and the abundance of accessible ligand-binding sites facilitate the formation of 2D MOF nanosheets. The resulting V2CT x MXene-PMOF hybrid demonstrated remarkable proton-conducting properties, making it a promising candidate for applications in electronics, sensing, and electrochemical devices [109]. This approach not only helps in stabilizing MXene surfaces but also broadens its functional utility in advanced material applications. Recently, to prevent MXene oxidation, a facile yet effective strategy has been reported for hybridizing Ti3C2 MXene with pillared-layer 3D porous MOF nanosheets, resulting in MXene@Ni-MOF composites [110]. In this hybrid structure, interactions between the surface functional groups of MXene and the organic ligands of Ni-MOF play a crucial role in inhibiting the oxidation of MXene and expanding its interlayer spacing. Interestingly, in the Ti 2p spectrum of MXene@Ni-MOF, the characteristic peak for TiO2, typically attributed to the surface oxidation of MXene, is absent. This absence indicates that the chemical interaction between the organic ligands of Ni-MOF and the abundant interlayer functional groups of MXene effectively suppresses MXene oxidation. This strong interaction prevents the formation of TiO2, thereby preserving the integrity of MXene's structure and improving its stability. MXene serves as a conductive matrix, enhancing the overall electrical conductivity of Ni-MOF and preventing the agglomeration of Ni-MOF nanosheets. Additionally, the pillared-layer 3D porous framework contributes to the composite structural stability. Due to the synergistic effects between MXene and Ni-MOF, the electrode exhibits significantly improved specific capacitance, showcasing potential in energy storage applications. The notable advancements in these fields have established it as a key area of research and development, resulting in numerous scholarly publications on the synthesis, structure, and potential applications of MOF/MXene hybrid materials. The scientific community is actively investigating various aspects of these hybrid composite materials, leading to a significant and continuously growing body of literature (Fig. 2 ). The present review provides a comprehensive assessment of the synthesis methodologies for MOF/MXene hybrids, with an emphasis on scalable production methods and the seamless integration of MOF/MXene sheets and nanoarrays. In particular, significant recent advances in the fields of supercapacitors and ion batteries are examined by delving into the various morphologies and properties of these hybrids. The review also highlights the recent strides in optimizing these nanoarchitectures in order to improve their efficiency and capability, while confronting significant challenges and outlining prospective research directions. While published reviews on MOF/MXene integration are limited, the present article provides a thorough overview of the current research state on the combination of these two highly impactful materials. It discusses their synthesis and explores the potential applications of their integration in the development of hybrid energy storage systems, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . The MOF/MXene hybrids are recognized as transformative materials with substantial potential to drive innovation across a wide range of scientific fields, including energy storage, environmental applications, and electronics. Through an in-depth analysis of the current advancements and future potential, this review paper provides insight into how these materials could improve this emerging sector. This approach enables the design of high-performance materials tailored for specific applications that demand high breakdown strength, high polarization, and minimized hysteresis, thus presenting an exciting avenue for future research and development. 2 Evolution of MOF/MXene hybrid materials: Key milestones 2.1 Mxene structures: A decade of evolution on materials science The discovery of the unique physical properties of single- and few-layer graphene in 2004 marked a turning point in the study of 2D materials [111]. This finding propelled graphene to the forefront of scientific inquiry and opened avenues for exploring other 2D materials with layered structures. These materials include hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), dichalcogenides, and layered oxides, all of which possess readily available layered precursors [112]. The rapid expansion of interest in 2D materials, driven by the demonstrated exceptional properties of graphene, led to a wave of research and development in the field. These new materials exhibit a range of electronic, optical, mechanical, and chemical properties that vary with the choice of element and structure [113–117]. The investigation into h-BN, dichalcogenides, and layered oxides has uncovered materials with distinct characteristics suitable for diverse applications in areas including electronics, energy storage, and catalysis [118–122]. In this period, the existing 2D materials were predominantly characterized by semiconductors, semimetals, and insulators, each exhibiting limited electronic conductivity and carrier concentrations. Moreover, the challenge of producing these materials in quantities suitable for other applications beyond microelectronics presented a significant barrier. Most solution-processed 2D materials, with the exception of graphene and hexagonal boron nitride, were constrained by small flake sizes due to weak mechanical properties, leading to sheet fracture during delamination. Additionally, the inherent hydrophobicity and instability of many materials when exposed to air further restricted their practical use. The advent of a class of 2D carbides and nitrides which are marked by their metallic conductivity, hydrophilic nature, ease of processing, and production of relatively large flakes in high yields, were highly recommended in the field of materials science. Keeping this in mind, the dynamic research domain surrounding 2D materials beyond graphene continues to give new ideas to scientists and engineers. As a proof of concept, early transition metal carbides and nitrides were considered as notable materials due to their remarkable properties, including high metallic electrical conductivity, exceptional hardness, and superior chemical stability [123]. However, the strong covalent and metallic bonding between transition metal atoms and carbon or nitrogen atoms in these materials posed a significant challenge in reducing their dimensionality from bulk 3D solids to nanostructures such as 2D sheets and 1D nanoribbons or nanotubes. Innovative approaches were required to overcome these obstacles and create nanomaterials from these compounds. In a key moment for materials science in 2011, a team of researchers demonstrated that immersing the MAX phase Ti3AlC2 in HF at room temperature could selectively etch away the aluminum layers, resulting in the formation of a 2D titanium carbide (Ti3C2) for the first time [124]. The following year, they further established that this selective etching technique could be extended to other MAX phases containing aluminum, which is a common element in MAX phases [125]. This study led to the creation of MXenes as a new family of materials that reflects their origin from MAX phases and their 2D structure [126]. MXenes can incorporate more than one “M” element, manifesting in two distinct forms: solid solutions and ordered phases (Fig. 4 ) [127–132]. Solid solutions involve a random distribution of two different transition metals within the M layers, while ordered MXenes feature alternating single or double layers of different transition metals, such as titanium and molybdenum, within a 2D carbide structure [123,133–135]. This structural diversity leads to an array of material behaviors and potential uses. The periodic table includes a broad spectrum of elements utilized in MXene synthesis, the primary distinction among MAX phase structures lies in the number of MX layers that separate each A layer (Fig. 4). From these combinations, over 40 distinct configurations are successfully produced [123], and more than 100 potential stoichiometries are predicted up to now [136,137]. This remarkable adaptability arises from MXenes' structural flexibility and the ability to fine-tune their surface chemistry, enabling these materials to serve a variety of applications across fields such as energy storage [138–140], electronics [141–143], and catalysis [144–146]. Along with time, the scientific community has recognized that incorporating alloying into traditional ternary MAX phases offers substantial potential for advancing applications and deepening scientific understanding. Variations in the “M”, “A”, and “X” sites enable the creation of new materials with tailored properties [147–149]. These modifications also allow for chemically ordered structures within MAX phases, which can manifest in either out-of-plane (o-MAX) or in-plane (i-MAX) order, both of which involve ordering of the “M” elements. In this context, in 2017, a notable advancement in the field was the introduction of a family of quaternary, chemically-ordered in-plane MAX phases, known as i-MAX phases [150]. This development led to the discovery of new material combinations and structures [151]. The first member of the i-MAX family, and its corresponding i-MXene derivative, exhibited promising properties, including a high volumetric capacitance of approximately 1150 F cm−3 [150]. These early successes inspired further research into a variety of i-MAX phases and their corresponding i-MXenes, both theoretically and experimentally. By exploring the chemical ordering and properties of i-MAX phases and i-MXenes, researchers continue to uncover new possibilities for the future of materials science. On the other hand, Ponce-Pérez et al. [152] conducted a comprehensive study on the thermodynamic stability of the o-MAX solid solution Mo x V4-xAlC3 across the compositional range of 0 ≤ x ≤ 4. Their findings demonstrate that the lattice parameter an increase with the incorporation of Mo, while the c parameter exhibits maximum expansion at x = 2.5, followed by a contraction as Mo content increases further. Mo atoms were found to randomly occupy VI sites until the ordered out-of-plane Mo2V2AlC3 alloy is formed. To evaluate the thermodynamic stability of these alloys, the defect formation energy formalism was employed, revealing five stable compounds. Under V-rich to Mo-moderate conditions, the pristine V4AlC3 MAX phase remains stable. In V-poor conditions, the solid solutions with x = 0.5, 1, and 1.5, along with the o-MAX Mo2V2AlC3 phase, are thermodynamically stable. The electron localization function line profiles and Bader charge analysis indicated that the V-C interactions are predominantly ionic, while the Mo-C bonds exhibit covalent character. Furthermore, the exfoliation energy required to obtain an MXene layer from the o-MAX phase was calculated to be approximately 0.4 eV Å−2. The calculations confirmed that MXenes exfoliated from the o-MAX phases with identical Mo content and atomic arrangement are thermodynamically stable. 2.2 The key steps in the evolution of MOF architectures over a quarter-century of development The evolution of MOFs has been a transformative development in materials science, offering unprecedented opportunities for creating materials with precisely tailored properties [153,154]. MOFs represent a remarkable combination of inorganic and organic chemistry, leading to the synthesis of novel materials with exceptional characteristics [155–158]. These frameworks are built by combining metal ions with charged organic linkers such as carboxylates, resulting in crystalline, porous structures [159–162]. MOFs are a product of reticular chemistry, which emerged as a solution to the question of how to crystallize porous structures through the use of robust, precisely oriented bonds [163,164]. This approach drew inspiration from the distinct synthesis methods in solid-state organic and inorganic chemistry [165,166]. Organic synthesis typically focuses on discrete structures, while inorganic synthesis yields extended architectures with less control over size and shape. This evolution of MOFs began in 1995 when Prof. Yaghi's research team first synthesized a reticular framework by binding metal ions to charged organic linkers [167]. This discovery led to the formation of crystalline, 2D structures with unique properties. Since then, the development of MOFs has expanded rapidly, with the creation of a diverse array of materials offering unparalleled control over their pore size, shape, and functionality (Fig. 5 ) [57]. Beyond modifying the metal centers and organic ligands to achieve convenient tunability of dimensions, morphology, and porosity in MOFs (Fig. 5), these characteristics can also be tunable in a precise way by changing the synthetic procedures. For example, the pyrolysis of MOFs at high temperatures in inert environments is a critical process for improving their properties for energy storage applications. This technique not only enhances the surface area of the resulting materials but also significantly boosts ionic and electronic transport properties. During pyrolysis, the organic linkers in MOFs decompose, resulting in the formation of porous carbon materials. This process often leads to a significant increase in surface area compared to the original MOFs. Such an enhancement is beneficial as it provides additional active sites for ion storage and improves overall porosity, which is crucial for efficient ion diffusion during electrochemical processes. The increased porosity facilitates better accessibility and interaction between electrolytes and the electrode material, ultimately enhancing the performance of energy storage devices like batteries and supercapacitors [168]. The pyrolysis process is also essential for enhancing the electronic conductivity of materials. During the transformation of MOFs into carbon-based structures, graphitic domains can form within the carbon matrix, leading to improved conductivity. This enhanced conductivity enables more rapid charge transport during energy discharge and charging cycles, which is crucial for applications that demand swift energy release. Specifically, materials derived from MOFs via controlled pyrolysis can demonstrate enhanced stability and prolonged cycling longevity, essential attributes for achieving commercial viability in energy storage applications. The synergistic effect of increased surface area and improved conductivity contributes to higher specific capacitance and energy density in the pyrolyzed materials [169]. Despite the significance of these enhancements, the existing literature often lacks thorough discussions on the complex interplay between pyrolysis conditions, material properties, and their subsequent performance in energy storage applications. Highlighting this relationship would offer valuable insights into the underlying mechanisms and guide future efforts in the development of high-performance energy storage materials. More in-depth studies focused on these aspects could significantly advance the field and optimize the use of MOF-derived materials in energy technologies. In 1999, a significant step occurred in the synthesis of MOF-5, a MOF known for its high porosity and robustness. MOF-5 is constructed by linking octahedral Zn4O(CO2)6 clusters with ditopic 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate units to form a cubic framework [170]. This strong structural foundation allows for easy gas sorption measurements, which in turn has propelled advancements in the field of chemistry and materials science. Building on MOF-5, Yaghi et al. employed modifications to the length and functional groups of aromatic carboxylic acid ligands to create a series of MOFs [171]. These MOFs share the same topological structure as MOF-5, but offer a variety of pore sizes, including ultra-large-pore structures. In 2005, MOF-74 was synthesized for the first time, marking another advancement in the development of MOFs with diverse chemical properties [172]. In 2016, Yaghi et al. synthesized the first covalent MOFs (MOF-901), introducing new frameworks by combining metal-organic and covalent-organic structures [173]. This combination involved the synthesis of hexagonal six-connected Ti (IV) clusters, such as [Ti6O6(OiPr)6(AB)6] (where AB represents 4-aminobenzoate and OiPr is isopropoxide). By reacting Ti(OiPr)4 with 4-aminobenzoic acid, oriented coordination bonds were formed between the metal and the carboxylic acid, exposing six aldehyde groups on the surface of the metal clusters. These exposed aldehyde groups proved critical for facilitating the formation of imine-bonded frameworks. In 2018, Chen et al. [174] introduced the methodology for constructing a functionalized hollow structure from MOF@polymer as composite using the Kirkendall effect. This method enabled the fine-tuning of electronic properties at an active center through near-range coordination with nitrogen and longer-range interactions with sulfur and phosphorus. This design led to the development of a catalyst composed of single iron atomic sites anchored within a nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur co-doped hollow carbon polyhedron (Fe-SAs/NPS-HC). This structure demonstrated exceptional performance in oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) in alkaline media and found application in zinc-air batteries and hydrogen-air fuel cells. The creation of Fe-SAs/NPS-HC involves the encapsulation of single iron atoms within a hollow carbon framework that integrates multiple dopants (N, P, and S). The co-doping of these elements enhances the electronic structure of the active center, resulting in improved catalytic properties. Specifically, nitrogen contributes to near-range electronic modulation, while sulfur and phosphorus offer beneficial long-range interactions that further optimize the catalyst’s performance. The superior ORR performance of Fe-SAs/NPS-HC in alkaline media can be attributed to the catalyst's ability to facilitate efficient electron transfer and oxygen adsorption. These properties enable more effective catalysis in energy conversion applications. In zinc-air batteries, the catalyst's enhanced ORR capabilities lead to improved energy density and power output, while in hydrogen-air fuel cells, the catalyst's high efficiency and stability contribute to overall system performance. After all the success of MOF structures, another area of interest is the development of stimuli-responsive MOFs, which can undergo structural changes in response to external stimuli [175–179]. These smart materials offer exciting opportunities for controlled release and targeted delivery of molecules, as well as for applications in sensors and actuators. With the technological development, computational modeling has played a crucial role in guiding the evolution of MOF architectures nowadays. Advanced simulations allow researchers to predict the stability and properties of new frameworks before synthesis, accelerating the discovery of novel materials [180,181]. Machine learning algorithms are also being employed to identify trends and patterns in existing MOF data, providing insights into the design of next-generation frameworks [182]. 2.3 MOF/MXene hybrid materials: Key milestones Since the initial publication on MOF/MXene composites in 2017, there has been a noticeable rise in annual research publications on this topic, reflecting growing interest among scientists (Fig. 2). This surge in attention highlights the versatility and potential of MOF/MXene composites across various scientific disciplines. Fig. 6 highlights the expanding application of these composites in multiple areas over recent years. The development of MOF/MXene hybrid materials is driven by several key factors. MXenes, known for their negatively charged surface groups, serve as ideal platforms for MOF growth, facilitating the creation of stable composites. This integration not only mitigates the agglomeration of MXene and MOF nanoparticles but also maximizes available surface area for enhanced performance. Additionally, the conductive properties of the MXene framework contribute to the formation of efficient channels for conductivity, expediting ion diffusion. The strong interfacial interactions between MXene and MOFs play a crucial role in bolstering the structural integrity and durability of these composites. Moreover, the adaptable crystal structures and diverse morphologies of MOFs enable these hybrids to be tailored for a range of applications. First, Zhao et al. [183] synthesized a novel hybrid material by combining 2D cobalt 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (Co-BDC) with Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets through an interdiffusion reaction process. This hybrid demonstrated superior performance in the oxygen evolution reaction, achieving a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.64 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode outperforming standard IrO2-based catalysts and matching or exceeding advanced transition-metal-based catalysts. The Co-BDC layer contributed a porous structure and large active surface area, while the conductive and hydrophilic Ti3C2T x nanosheets facilitated rapid charge and ion transfer at the Ti3C2T x -Co-BDC interface and enabled efficient access of aqueous electrolyte to Co-BDC's active sites. The hybrid was also used to construct an air cathode for a zinc-air battery, successfully powering an LED, highlighting for the first time the potential of in situ MXene@2D-MOF hybrids in energy storage applications. In 2018, Wang's research team explored the use of Co-MOF and Ti3C2T x for creating a high-performance supercapacitor electrode [184]. Their study involved the in-situ hydrothermal synthesis of a novel composite material, Co-MOF/Ti3C2T x , grown on a Ni foam electrode without the need for binders. This combinational method produced an electrode with a high specific capacitance and impressive cycle stability. The gravimetric capacitance reached up to 2872.5 F g−1 for the Co-MOF@Ni foam electrode and an even higher 3741 F g−1 for the Co-MOF/Ti3C2T x @Ni composite. The Co-MOF/Ti3C2T x @Ni electrode offers potential for use in high-performance supercapacitors with aqueous electrolytes, thanks to its excellent conductivity and redox activity. One year later, a novel electrochemical sensing platform has been developed to detect organophosphorus pesticides with ultra-high sensitivity [185]. This platform combines MOF-derived MnO2/Mn3O4 and Ti3C2 MXene/Au nanoparticle composites, resulting in remarkable signal amplification and exceptional electrochemical performance. The three-dimensional MnO2/Mn3O4 microcuboids derived from Mn-MOF consist of vertically aligned nanosheets, which enhance the platform's specific surface area and environmental compatibility. When optimized, the biosensor effectively detects methamidophos across a wide concentration range with strong linearity and an ultra-low detection limit of 1.4 × 10−13 M, far surpassing European Union MRLs for methamidophos [186]. This biosensor's successful application in real samples shows exceptional recoveries up to 101.3%, highlighting its potential for monitoring pesticide residues and other harmful chemicals in the environment. In addition, and taking advantage of the combination of these two powerful materials in different engineering sectors, a novel hierarchical Co-Co layered double hydroxide/Ti3C2T X nanosheets (Co-Co LDH/TNS) nanoarray was developed, in 2020 by Chen et al. [187], using an in-situ MOF-derived method. This three-dimensional structure integrates the active Co species with conductive MXene to form a nanosheet architecture that enhances photogenerated charge separation and electron transfer. These features lead to a significant increase in the CO2-to-CO conversion rate under illumination, accompanied by a high apparent quantum efficiency of 0.92% and excellent stability. The study showcases the potential of 3D hybrid MXene structures for CO2 photoreduction, offering insights into optimizing photocatalytic performance through the rational design of complex hierarchical materials. On other hand, MXene's practical use in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) is significantly hindered by its limited theoretical capacitance and the tendency for layers to stack back together. Aiming at this issue, in 2019, Sun et al. proposed a novel approach to address the limitations of MXene materials in LIBs [188]. They devised a strategy to create MXene-based hollow frameworks by electrostatically assembling negatively charged MXene nanosheets with positively charged layered double hydroxide (LDH) derived from ZIF-67 polyhedron. Subsequent thermal annealing produced hollow transition metal oxides@MXene frameworks, which were used as anode materials for LIBs. This morphological design leverages the 3D conductive network and mechanical strength of MXene to enhance charge transfer and accommodate volume expansion of the internal Co-O/Co2Mo3O8 TMOs. In turn, the Co-O/Co2Mo3O8 hollow polyhedron structure stabilizes MXene by preventing its aggregation and offering superior lithium storage capacity. The Co-O/Co2Mo3O8@MXene frameworks achieved a high reversible capacity of 947 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1, retained 436 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1, and maintained good stability over 1200 cycles. Hence, their research work demonstrates the potential of MOF@MXene-based materials in high-performance LIB applications. In the same context, in 2021, Yu's research team introduced a novel aerogel structure combining MOFs and MXene to form a three-dimensional hierarchical porous network [189]. This arrangement effectively prevents the aggregation of MXene, creating an ultralight, conductive scaffold. From the MOFs@MXene aerogel, they synthesized a composite material featuring a 3D porous MXene aerogel with hollow CoS nanoboxes. This composite, known as (CoS NP@NHC)@MXene, leverages the interconnected MXene network and the hierarchical porous structure to optimize electron and ion transport, benefiting from the fine nanocrystallization of the CoS phase. The (CoS NP@NHC)@MXene hybrid exhibits superior electrochemical properties across lithium-ion, sodium-ion, and potassium-ion batteries, largely due to its enhanced charge transfer kinetics at the interface. It also demonstrates excellent rate performance under high mass loading, along with substantial volumetric energy and power density. These attributes highlight its potential for practical applications in energy storage devices in general. The synthesis method described can be adapted to produce other porous MXene-aerogel-based materials for a range of applications. In 2022, Lee et al. [190] explored the potential of direct growth of Co-MOF structures on a highly conductive, flexible MX-CNF substrate. Initially, they developed the MX-CNF through electrospinning and carbonization, followed by the direct growth of Co-MOF. This Co-MOF@MX-CNF served as a starting point for creating two types of functional multi-component electrodes. For capacitive electrodes, carbonizing Co-MOF@MX-CNF led to the formation of highly porous carbon nano spikes with incorporated Co nanoparticles (Co-PC@MX-CNF). For battery-type electrodes, in-situ oxidation with KMnO4 transformed Co-PC@MX-CNF into MnO2-Co3O4@MX-CNF, featuring porous MnO2 nanosheets anchored on a Co3O4-PC@MX-CNF base. These electrodes were then integrated into a flexible and wearable quasi-solid-state hybrid supercapacitor (FW-QSS-HSC) using a PVA-KOH gel electrolyte. The assembledFW-QSS-HSC demonstrated an energy density of 72.5 Wh kg−1 and a power density of 832.4 kW kg−1, along with excellent flexibility. This makes it a promising power source for flexible electronic devices and wearable technologies. Recently, interest in MXene@MOF hybrids and their derivatives has grown significantly in the energy storage sector. The unique properties of MXene@MOF hybrids make them well-suited for advanced energy storage applications. These hybrids offer improved energy storage capabilities through enhanced ion and electron transport, which is critical for applications such as batteries and supercapacitors. Additionally, MXene@MOF hybrids demonstrate excellent structural stability and cycling performance, contributing to their potential for long-term use in energy storage systems. As research progresses, the adaptability of these materials allows for further optimization and customization to meet the specific requirements of different energy storage technologies. Based on this interesting aspect, in the subsequent sections of this review, we will focus on the role of MXene@MOF hybrids within the context of energy storage applications, exploring their potential to enhance performance and efficiency in this sector. 3 Advanced synthesis strategies and functionalization for MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures 3.1 Strategies for effective synthesis 3.1.1 In situ synthesis The formation of MXene-MOF hybrids involves a range of synthesis methods, such as in-situ [191–193], self-assembly [194,195], electrochemical synthesis method [196,197], ultrasonication [198,199], hydrothermal, stirring, and solvothermal techniques [200,201]. By merging MXenes with MOFs, various forms of hybrid structures can be created, including MXene@MOF composites, their derivatives, and other combinations (Fig. 7 ). Many research efforts have been focused on engineering hybrid materials with specific architectures and functionalities. For instance, MXene nanosheets' hydroxyl groups promote uniform dispersion in aqueous media, aiding in the assembly process. However, the large layer spacing between the nanosheets leads to weak interfacial interactions and limited gelation capability, which presents challenges in creating mechanically robust, chemically stable, and durable MXene-based macrostructures. To overcome these obstacles, Qiao et al. [105] recently achieved an aqueous dispersion of MXene by etching and delaminating dense Ti3AlC2 MAX precursors (Fig. 8 a). This approach supports the production of multifunctional magnetic MXene composites using a dual physical and chemical cross-linking strategy. This strategy helps enhance the stability and robustness of MXene-based macrostructures to fabricate new MOF/MXene systems. To this end, synthesis methods generally fall into in situ and ex situ techniques. In situ synthesis aligns with conventional MOF synthesis approaches, where a one-pot process is predominantly employed. Ex situ synthesis, on the other hand, typically utilizes vacuum filtration and self-assembly methods to merge MXene and pre-synthesized MOFs [196,202,203]. The in-situ synthesis method is a widely used approach for creating MXene/MOF composites due to its straightforward and manageable process. This method involves mixing MXene with a solution of MOF precursors and allowing the reaction to take place under controlled conditions over time, resulting in the formation of MXene/MOF composites. MXenes contain abundant surface functional groups which facilitate binding with metal ions or organic ligands, thus providing sufficient nucleation sites for MOF formation. By fine-tuning factors such as reactant concentrations, solvent, temperature, pressure, and reaction duration, the properties of the final product can be customized according to the desired application. In the first study [183], when Zhao et al. introduced their new hybrid composite, they reported an in situ approach to hybridize Co-BDC on both sides of Ti3C2T x nanosheets using an interdiffusion reaction-assisted process. This method, performed in a test tube, utilized a layered solvent system of N, N-dimethylformamide/acetonitrile mixtures with varying volume ratios. The MXene surface groups enabled the adsorption of Co2+ through electrostatic interactions. As MXene nanosheets with electrostatically bound Co2+ sank to the middle solvent layer, Co2+ coordinated with BDC, leading to the formation of the Ti3C2T x -Co-BDC composite, which eventually precipitated to the bottom of the test tube. This composite retained MXene's original sheet-like structure while the Co-BDC layers coated the surface, giving it a rough texture. Given the potential of MOFs for structural control and chemical diversity, numerous studies have employed the in-situ synthesis method to create functional MOF-based composites. Pang's research group, for instance, developed Ti3C2 MXene@pillared-layer [Ni(thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylate)(4,4′-bipyridine)] n MOF composites with remarkable conductivity and cyclic stability using this synthesis route [110]. The pillared-layer Ni-MOF structure, with its Ni–N coordination bonds, offers enhanced structural stability in accordance with the hard-soft-acid-base principle. The MXene serves as a stabilizing platform for the Ni-MOF nanosheets, promoting efficient charge transfer and addressing the conductivity limitations of Ni-MOF while preventing its agglomeration. Additionally, the strong interaction between the organic ligands of Ni-MOF and the functional groups on MXene's surface shields the MXene from oxidation and widens its layer spacing, thereby enabling rapid ion transport. In addition, Qin et al. [204] have successfully engineered nanosheets of Ti3C2-QD/Ni-MOF through an ultrasonication approach involving the reaction mixture of Ni metal salt, 1,4-BDC, and Ti3C2 quantum dots. This in-situ synthesis method proves to be a reliable means of creating MXene@MOF hybrids while preserving the distinct properties of the individual components. The novel composites of 0D/2D MXene@MOF, synthesized using the simple yet effective self-assembly process, was serving as an adaptable platform that provides an abundance of metal-active sites, thereby facilitating the adsorption and activation of nitrogen molecules. Moreover, introducing co-catalysts into MOFs is a promising strategy to mitigate electron-hole pair recombination. However, achieving stronger interactions between MOFs and co-catalysts remains challenging. Such interactions are crucial for efficient charge transfer, which can significantly improve the overall performance of the system. Aiming at this issue, Shi et al. [205] have introduced a new method to produce a tightly coupled MOF heterojunction with improved charge-carrier separation. They synthesized a UiO-66-NH2(Zr/Ti) and carboxyl-functionalized MXene (UZT/CFMX) composite using a carboxyl group-assisted coordination approach (Fig. 8e). This process forms coordination bonds between the MOF and MXene, enhancing their interaction and reducing electron-hole recombination, which boosts water reduction efficiency. The optimized interactions lead to significant improvements in photocatalytic activity. The UZT/CFMX composite exhibits approximately four times the performance of a similar UiO-66-NH2(Zr/Ti) and MXene composite without the coordination bond integration. Recently, the in-situ phase transformation technique has emerged as a new synthesis route method to creating MOF/MXene hybrid materials. In this strategy, MXene nanosheets combine with intermediary agents such as positively charged metal hydroxides, which are then transformed in-situ into MOFs under controlled conditions. In this vein, in 2022, Sun's research group introduced a method for preparing MXene composite material through an in situ transformation process [206]. Their approach involved transforming LDH nanosheets hosted on 2D materials into small Prussian blue analogue nanoparticles (Fig. 8f). The flexibility of this method was showcased by altering the composition of LDH and the type of 2D substrates used. The 2D nanosheets serve as conductive platforms that not only facilitate charge transfer but also attract LDH through electrostatic interactions, preventing the aggregation of Prussian blue analogue during the transformation process. Interestingly, the versatility of the in-situ phase transformation approach has been further validated by substituting MXene with graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets. This modification demonstrates the adaptability of the strategy, allowing for different 2D substrates to be used in the formation of MOF-based hybrids. The use of GO nanosheets in place of MXene underscores the potential for this method to be applied across a variety of 2D materials, enlarging the scope of potential functional composites. On the other hand, considering the importance of stability, the in-situ synthesis method has been found to enhance the hydrothermal stability of widely used MOFs by integrating MXene layers. Gu et al. [207] applied this strategy to improve the hydrothermal stability of the MOF HKUST-1 by incorporating Ti3C2T x MXene. The resultant hybrid material, synthesized through a combination of HKUST-1 and MXene using this strategy, demonstrated superior hydrothermal stability and enhanced catalytic activity compared to pure HKUST-1. This approach involved using HF to remove the aluminum layer from the MXene, then introducing copper ions to its surface through sonication, followed by hydrothermal synthesis with varying amounts of Ti3C2T x . The resulting hybrid material exhibited improved performance in styrene oxide ring-opening reactions and maintained catalytic activity over multiple cycles. Overall, the in-situ synthesis plays a vital role in achieving stable bonding and strong interactions between components, which significantly influences the performance of the resulting composites. It is important to highlight that the success of in-situ synthesis of MXene/MOF hybrids relies on the precise control of several key parameters, including temperature, pH, precursor concentration, and reaction time, is essential to ensure successful synthesis. In the in-situ synthesis of MOF/MXene composites, controlling the temperature is essential. The reaction temperature has a significant impact on the rate of precursor reactions and the resultant properties of the hybrids. Generally, temperatures ranging from 100 to 180 °C are employed. While higher temperatures can expedite the reaction, they also pose the risk of oxidizing the MXenes, necessitating careful monitoring to maintain their desirable characteristics [208]. The pH level of the synthesis solution is crucial for the stability of both MXenes and the metal precursors utilized in MOFs. A balanced pH range of 6–9 is generally recommended, as it ensures that MXenes retain their structural integrity while promoting optimal coordination between metal ions and organic ligands, thereby facilitating the effective formation of MOFs. Deviations from this pH range may lead to instability in the MXenes or insufficient formation of the MOFs. The concentration of precursors also influences the in-situ synthesis of composite materials. Higher concentrations can accelerate the nucleation and growth of MOFs, potentially simplifying the formation process; however, they may also result in agglomeration or uneven distributions. This variability in morphology can adversely affect the electrochemical performance of the resulting hybrids, highlighting the importance of careful management of precursor concentrations during synthesis. The duration of the reaction is another critical parameter that needs optimization during the in-situ synthesis process. Adequate reaction time facilitates thorough interaction between MXenes and MOF precursors, promoting the formation of a robust composite structure. Conversely, insufficient reaction time may result in incomplete reactions. Achieving an optimal balance in reaction time is essential for enhancing the performance of the composites in practical applications [209]. In conclusion, a comprehensive analysis of the different parameters affecting the in-situ synthesis of MOF/MXene hybrids is vital for effectively addressing the complexities involved in their development. By meticulously optimizing these synthesis conditions, researchers can enhance the stability and performance of the resulting composites for applications in energy storage systems. 3.1.2 Ex situ synthesis While in-situ synthesis is promising for producing MOF/MXene hybrids, the instability and oxidation of certain MXenes during the process limit the range of viable hybrids. To preserve the structural and chemical properties of MXene, ex situ synthesis emerges as a key alternative. This method involves combining pre-synthesized MOFs with MXene using methods such as mixing, self-assembly, or electrochemical approaches. Ex situ synthesis offers greater control and flexibility since it avoids potential environmental issues during MOF synthesis and is not affected by the conditions of the MOF formation process (Fig. 8b–d). As a proof of concept, Chen et al. [210] have demonstrated an ex situ technique to creating an electrochemical sensor for L-Tryptophan detection by combining a straw-sheaf-like Ce-MOF with few-layer Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets. This sensor was produced through a direct mixing method, providing a cost-effective and environmentally friendly path to a high-performance sensor. The Ce-MOF/Ti3C2T x MXene hybrid offers a low detection limit and a broad linear range for L-Tryptophan, making it particularly suitable for rapid analysis in blood serum samples. This work marks the first application of Ti3C2T x MXene in detecting L-Tryptophan, opening new avenues for the ex situ MOF/Ti3C2T x MXene-based electrochemical sensor synthesis development. Moreover, the combination of cationic polymer-modified MOFs with negatively charged MXene materials can result in functional heterostructures. For example, integrating MXene with Ni-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid nanosheets using polyquaternium-6 homopolymer leads to improved composite materials. Similarly, polyquaternium-6 homopolymer modification of V2CT x MXene allows it to form composites with negatively charged 2D Cu-HHTP, showcasing the potential of such combinations. Wong's research team explores this potential by creating heterostructures of MOFs and V2CT x MXenes using ex situ synthesis method [211]. This approach leverages the strengths of both materials and addresses challenges such as nanosheet aggregation while enhancing electrical conductivity for efficient charge transport. By incorporating 2D Cu-HHTP and modified V2CT x MXene through direct assembly in a solution-phase, they develop composites with alternately stacked nanosheets. The Cu-HHTP/MX composite benefits from the addition of MX nanosheets, which boost conductivity and mitigate aggregation during charge and discharge cycles. Cu-HHTP serves as an active layer for zinc ion (Zn2+) storage and acts as a separator for MX nanosheets. This lamellar structure facilitates rapid Zn2+ insertion and extraction, resulting in increased specific capacity and improved rate performance. The reversible structural changes in the Cu-HHTP/MX heterostructure contribute to a prolonged cycle life, indicating its potential for long-term applications. Recent advancements have also demonstrated the feasibility of directly combining MOFs with MXene without relying on surface charge modulators. Two main methods have been used to address challenges in this area. One approach involves thermal treatment, converting 2D porphyrin paddlewheel frameworks into conductive CoS1.097/nitrogen-doped carbon composites, though this process can compromise the original porous structure and increase initial consumption [212]. Another method incorporates graphene nanosheets into MOF layers, creating a flexible MOF/graphene oxide electrode through vacuum-assisted filtration and HI-reduction [213,214]. Huang's study introduces a novel method for creating hybrids of MXene and metal-porphyrin frameworks using vacuum-assisted filtration [203]. An interlayer hydrogen-bonded MOF/MXene hybrid film was crafted through filtration of 2D ultrathin MXene nanosheets and Cu-TCPP nanosheets. The MXene's surface terminations form hydrogen bonds with carboxy groups in the metal-porphyrin frameworks nanosheets, creating a conductive network that supports rapid ionic and electronic transport within a porous structure. This interlayer hydrogen bond between MXene and metal-porphyrin frameworks helps prevent self-restacking of the materials and mitigates volume changes due to phase separation and structural collapse during fast charge/discharge cycles. The resulting hybrid film exhibits enhanced durability, rate capability, and cyclability, even under mechanical stress such as bending and folding, while maintaining structural integrity. While creating MXene/MOF hybrid composites using van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds is a common approach, mechanochemical synthesis has been less explored due to challenges such as poor product uniformity and potential structural damage to the raw materials [197,215,216]. Despite these drawbacks, physical mixing remains a straightforward and practical method for producing hybrids, offering ease of processing and preparation [216,217]. Based on different synthesis strategies, in-situ synthesis involves the simultaneous formation of MXenes and MOFs, resulting in stronger interactions and improved stability between the two components. In this approach, MXenes are directly combined with MOF precursors, allowing chemical reactions to take place within a shared environment to create the composite [218]. This method typically promotes the formation of robust interfacial bonds, thereby enhancing structural integrity and electrochemical performance [197]. However, in-situ synthesis can limit control over the morphology and distribution of the MOF within the MXene matrix. The complexity of reaction parameters, including concentration, temperature, and duration, may result in variations in the final product, making it challenging to achieve the desired composite properties. Such variability can impact the performance of the composite in specific applications. In contrast, ex-situ synthesis involves preparing MOFs and MXenes separately before combining them to form the composite [197]. This approach allows for greater control over the properties of each component prior to assembly, enabling customization for specific functionalities. Techniques such as vacuum filtration or ultrasonication can be used to achieve uniform distribution and optimal loading of MOFs onto MXenes. However, a drawback of ex-situ synthesis is the potential for weaker interfacial bonding compared to in-situ synthesis. Since the components are prepared separately, incomplete integration may occur, reducing the overall stability and electrical conductivity of the composite. This limitation can affect the performance of the composite in applications where strong electronic interconnectivity is essential, such as in electrochemical devices. Ultimately, the selection between in-situ and ex-situ synthesis depends on the specific application and the targeted properties of MOF/MXene composites. In-situ synthesis is more suitable when strong interfacial interactions and stability are essential, while ex-situ synthesis is ideal for achieving tailored properties and precise control over morphology. 3.2 Functionalization strategies 3.2.1 Pre-synthetic approach Research on MOFs and MXenes is moving towards the development and synthesis of engineered materials tailored for specific applications. This effort will involve creating novel and functionalized structures as well as integrating existing architectures into new hybrid designs. Enhancing the molecular structure of these materials can be achieved through functionalization, which can be accomplished via two main approaches. For MOF structures, the first is the pre-synthetic approach, where functional moieties are added to the building blocks prior to forming the molecular backbone, allowing for precise control down to the atomic level. This can involve metal functionalization, linker functionalization, or varying linker lengths (Fig. 9 ). The second is the postsynthetic approach, or secondary modification, which introduces functional groups into the structure after the initial synthesis. This method provides an alternative pathway for fine-tuning the properties and performance of the material, ensuring it meets specific application requirements. Through these targeted strategies, the capabilities of MOF-based materials can be enhanced to address various challenges in energy storage and other fields. The synergistic interaction between MOFs and MXenes in composite materials not only mitigates the inherent drawbacks of MOFs but also introduces new functionalities. For instance, the improved electronic conductivity and stability enhance the overall performance and potential applications of the composites. Additionally, these materials can exhibit novel properties such as a template effect, which can guide the formation of nanostructures or support catalytic reactions. This section will delve into the unique functionalities that arise from the synergistic effects of MOF and MXene composites, highlighting how these combinations lead to enhanced materials. The integration of MXene nanosheets with MOFs creates a conductive network that significantly boosts the electronic conductivity of the MOFs. This combination allows MOFs to be incorporated within the interlayer spaces of MXene, preventing the self-stacking of MXene nanosheets. By doing so, the composite materials enhance the accessibility of the electrolyte, thereby exposing more electroactive sites. Moreover, this approach enlarges the channels available for electron and ion transport, contributing to improved performance in electrochemical applications. Ye et al. [219] demonstrate a method for fabricating 0D bimetallic selenides on 2D nitrogen-doped MXene using a process that involves the self-assembly of MOFs on MXene functionalized nanosheets, followed by an in situ selenization technique (Fig. 10 a). In this system, the MXene nanosheets serve as a substrate for catalysis, facilitating rapid electron and ion transport and preventing the aggregation of MOF-derived selenides during the lithium polysulfide conversion reaction. The MOF-derived selenides function as spacers, separating the MXene nanosheets and preventing their restacking. This separation maintains the active areas essential for polysulfide electrocatalysis. Furthermore, the MOF-derived selenides efficiently expedite the polysulfide redox reaction, thereby enhancing sulfur utilization and overall performance in related electrochemical processes. Moreover, considering that MXenes possess surfaces rich in functional groups, such as oxygen, hydroxyl, and fluoride groups, these functional groups play a crucial role in strengthening the chemical bond between MOFs and MXenes. The enhanced chemical connection not only promotes greater stability within the composite material but also shortens the pathways for ion and electron transfer. This improved connectivity is advantageous in electrochemical applications, as it can lead to faster and more efficient charge transfer processes. In this context, a related material system has been fabricated by self-assembling Ni-doped ZIF-67, through an incubation process using nickel nitrate as the nickel source [220]. Doping ZIF-67 with nickel significantly improves its electrochemical properties. During the in-situ crystallization process, the negatively charged MXene provides numerous heterogeneous nucleation sites for the NiCo-ZIF-67 formation, enabling the creation of an MXene/NiCo-MOF nano-heterostructure through alkali treatment of the Ni-doped ZIF-67. MXene acts as a conductive substrate that prevents the aggregation of NiCo-ZIF-67 particles, thereby enhancing the efficiency of ion transport in electrochemical reactions. The resulting composite electrodes exhibit substantial improvements in electrochemical performance, demonstrating clear synergistic effects between the MXene and NiCo-ZIF-67 components. The as-prepared composite electrode materials offer a higher density of electrochemical active sites and display enhanced electrode kinetics, which is crucial for energy storage and conversion applications. 3.2.2 The template effects The template effect in the context of MOF and MXene composites refers to the influence of a template on the electronic state and spatial configuration of a hybrid material. This effect arises when ligands coordinate with the template, resulting in modifications to the material's electronic properties and its three-dimensional structure. Templates can be a variety of substances, including organic molecules, inorganic molecules, organic-inorganic hybrids, polymers, and surfactants. By guiding the assembly and configuration of the hybrid, the template can contribute to enhanced functionalization and performance of the composite. These effects are particularly beneficial for optimizing properties such as electrical conductivity, ion transport, and specific surface area. The careful selection and incorporation of appropriate templates can lead to highly efficient materials. Additionally, during the synthesis process of MOFs, MXenes can also act as structure-directing or size-controlling agents. By varying the quantity of MXene used, researchers can manipulate the shape and size of MOF crystals [221]. This level of control over the morphology of MOFs is of great interest, as different shapes and sizes can dramatically influence the properties and performance of the resulting materials. The ability to customize the structure of MOFs through the use of MXenes opens up new opportunities for tailoring these materials for specific applications. For example, different shapes and sizes of MOFs can impact surface area, pore structure, and the availability of active sites, all of which are critical factors [222]. Zhang et al. [223] demonstrated the successful fabrication to induce the construction of Ni-MOF micro-belts using MXene as a key agent. MXenes, a unique class of 2D transition metal carbides and carbonitrides, offer high conductivity, tunable surface chemistry, and good stability. In their study, MXenes serve both as a substrate material to couple with Ni-MOFs and as structure-directing agents to shape Ni-MOFs into 2D micro-belts (Fig. 10b). The high surface area of MXenes provides additional electric-double layer capacitance, enhancing the overall electrochemical performance of the composite. Additionally, functional groups present on the MXene surface, such as fluoride and hydroxyl groups, act as redox sites and contribute faradaic pseudo-capacitance, highlighting the potential of MXenes in directing the morphology of MOFs while simultaneously improving the electrochemical properties of the resulting composite material. In the context of size change, an ultra-thin Ti2NT x MXene-wrapped MOFs-derived CoP hybrid was synthesized by Zong et al. [224], demonstrating its effectiveness as a low-cost, high-activity bifunctional catalyst. The limited interlayer distances in MXenes constrain the growth of MOFs between layers, allowing for precise control over the size of MOFs and resulting in more stable and efficient structures (Fig. 10c). The introduction of ultra-thin Ti2NT x MXene nanosheets not only increases the active sites of electrocatalytic electrodes but also enhances the stability of heterojunction catalysis. MOFs-derived CoP contributes to the improved intrinsic properties of the catalyst and helps regulate the electronic structure of the Ti2NT x @MOF-CoP heterostructure. In addition, Ruan et al. [225] reported a successful synthesis approach involving the modulation of MOFs with MXenes, resulting in the formation of Ti3C2-modulated CoNi2S4 dendrites using a two-step solvothermal process. Initially, they synthesized ZIF-67 nanosheet arrays on a nickel foam (NF) substrate in a mixture of cobalt nitrate and dimethyl imidazole. Subsequently, they conducted hydrothermal etching and sulfurization to produce NiCo-LDH on NF and CoNi2S4/MXene/NF, respectively. The addition of Ti3C2 suspension played a crucial role in transforming the morphology of the ZIF-derived sulfide. The resulting CoNi2S4/MXene/NF exhibited a dendrite morphology with each individual structure resembling a tree composed of a trunk and twigs. Time-dependent experiments helped shed light on the growth mechanism of CoNi2S4/MXene/NF. The unique dendritic structure and inherent properties of the sulfide and MXene combination contributed to the material's exceptional ability to store and release charges repeatedly with minimal performance degradation. These advances in synthesis, functionalization and the engineering of heterostructures are crucial for developing sustainable green energy solutions and reducing carbon emissions. 4 Insights into appropriate MOF/MXene interactions for stabilizing and improving the desired properties 4.1 Energy storage advantages of MOF/MXene unique architectures The potential benefits of MOF/MXene nanocomposites in the field of electrochemical energy storage have not been thoroughly investigated. However, these composite materials offer several advantageous properties, including hierarchical porosity and large surface areas, which contribute to improved ion insertion and enhanced energy storage capabilities (Fig. 11 ). The porous structure effectively traps dendrites and shuttling species, immobilizing them to ensure uninterrupted ion and electron transport [219]. The integration of MOFs within the interlayers of MXenes generates symmetric pores, acting as volume buffers that protect against expansion and provide structural stability. This setup minimizes the contact between the electrolyte and electrode interface, thus reducing resistance and enhancing overall performance. These attributes make MOF/MXene nanocomposites excellent candidates for next-generation energy storage applications, as their combination of porosity, surface area, and volume buffering enables superior ion transport and cycling stability [226]. MOFs and MXenes are characterized by structural defects and abundant active sites that play a crucial role in enabling certain reactions. These regions within the materials are key to their functionality and effectiveness in energy applications. Structural defects provide sites for interactions and can influence the material's properties, such as electronic conductivity and chemical reactivity [227,228]. In both MOFs and MXenes, the presence of active sites enhances their capacity to participate in specific reactions, making them valuable for tasks in energy storage. These active sites can interact with target molecules, facilitating transformations and storage processes. Tian et al. [229] successfully engineered hierarchical porous antimony metal on MXene paper using a universal one-step electrodeposition technique, creating robust, flexible, and free-standing anodes for high-performance potassium-ion batteries (PIBs). This MXene-based anode combines the unique properties of MXene and hierarchical porous metal-based anode materials, resulting in enhanced performance. Hierarchical porous material is robustly grown on MXene paper, allowing for a short diffusion distance for potassium ions and promoting fast, accessible ion transport. The porous structure effectively buffers volume expansion during the potassiation and depotassiation process, contributing to the stability of the anode. Additionally, the highly conductive and flexible MXene paper serves as an elastic current collector, facilitating efficient electron transport and accommodating volume changes during cycling. The composite design of the MXene-metal-based structure leads to remarkable stability and robust potassium storage performance when tested in PIBs. The resulting anodes exhibit high reversible capacity and excellent retention even after 500 cycles, highlighting their potential as a good solution for energy storage systems. Additionally, the interaction between surface functional groups and structural defects on MXene plays a key role in enhancing and customizing the material's characteristics. These interactions enable alterations in the properties of MXene, such as improving conductivity, capacitance, and proton transfer, which are critical for supporting electrochemical processes. Similarly, MOFs, as crystalline porous structures, incorporate different types of structural imperfections that influence their functionality. These defects include point defects, line defects, micro and mesoscale volume defects, and planar defects. The occurrence of these defects is dictated by synthesis conditions such as temperature and concentration. Point defects in MOFs often involve missing linkers in the original framework and defects in clusters. These structural irregularities can modify MOF properties such as porosity and stability, affecting their performance. Understanding and manipulating defects in both MXene/MOFs can provide opportunities to refine material properties for use in advanced energy storage. Qin et al. [204] introduced 0D/2D Ti3C2-QD/Ni-MOF composite synthesized through a simple and efficient self-assembly process. The 2D Ni-MOF serves as a versatile platform in the composite, offering numerous metal-active nodes that significantly enhance interfacial charge-transfer capabilities up to four times higher than that of the original 2D Ni-MOF. This improvement in charge transfer indicates the composite's potential compared to the pristine materials. Moreover, the integration of MXenes into the hybrid MOF materials aims to overcome inherent limitations within MOF structures, primarily attributed to their poor stability and low electronic conductivity. To address these shortcomings, aqueous electrolytes have emerged as a viable solution due to their cost-effectiveness, environmental compatibility, and high safety standards, thus offering promising solutions for sustainable energy storage solutions. A recent study led by Wong's research group introduced an alternately stacked MOF/MX heterostructure, featuring a 2D sandwich-like configuration rich in active sites, thereby enhancing electrical conductivity and ensuring exceptional structural robustness [211]. Through ex situ characterizations and theoretical modeling, a reversible intercalation mechanism of zinc ions and elevated electrical conductivity within the 2D heterostructure were elucidated. Electrochemical evaluations validated superior Zn2+ migration kinetics and favorable pseudocapacitive characteristics in the composite. Consequently, the composite material exhibited remarkable rate performance, delivering specific capacities of 260.1 mAh g−1 alongside long-term cycling stability over 1000 cycles. Expanding the repertoire and adaptability of MOF@MXene composites necessitates the exploration of novel combinations of MOFs and MXene species. Building upon the successes achieved with Ni/Co-based MOF@MXene hybrid electrodes, recent efforts have focused on synthesizing Zn-based MOF (ZIF-8)/MXene hybrids and a unique MXene substrate, V3C2T x , adorned with Ni-BDC. Wei et al. [230] introduced an innovative approach employing an ammonium phosphate solution to etch MOF (ZIF-67)/Ti3C2T x composites, yielding uniform NH4CoPO4 H2O/Ti3C2T x nanocomposite electrodes characterized by high conductivity. The resultant composite demonstrates exceptional electrochemical performance in a three-electrode system. Given its superior electrochemical properties and synthesis, the NH4CoPO4 H2O/Ti3C2T x composite emerges as a promising candidate for deployment in future energy storage devices, highlighting the potential of tailored MOF@MXene architectures in advancing electrochemical applications. 4.2 Impact of MOF/MXene hybridization on material properties It is well understood that the hybridization of MOFs with MXenes represents a transformative strategy for enhancing the physicochemical properties of these materials, making them suitable for advanced technologies. As previously discussed, several key factors should be considered in the fabrication of MOF/MXene hybrid materials. MXenes, with their abundant negatively charged surface functional groups, serve as reliable substrates for MOF growth, effectively enhancing the accessible surface area while minimizing the aggregation of both MOF nanoparticles and MXene nanosheets. Additionally, the highly conductive framework of MXenes provides efficient electron transport pathways and condensed ion-diffusion channels, significantly improving the electrochemical properties of the hybrids.The robust interfacial interactions between MXenes and MOFs further contribute to enhanced structural stability and mechanical integrity. The versatile morphologies and tunable crystalline structures of MOFs allow the hybrids to be customized for a wide range of specific applications. By combining the complementary properties of MXenes and MOFs, the inherent limitations of each component can be effectively mitigated, unlocking new possibilities and innovative applications through their synergistic effect. Briefly, the hybridization of these two classes of nanomaterials can significantly influence six critical areas. (i) Oxidation resistance: a key factor in the oxidation resistance of MOF/MXene composites is the protective barrier provided by MOFs. The intrinsic structure of MOFs enables them to encapsulate MXenes, creating a shield that minimizes exposure to environmental oxidants such as oxygen and water. This encapsulation is crucial, as MXenes are highly susceptible to oxidation, which can compromise their electrical conductivity and mechanical integrity. Additionally, the formation of composites reduces the effective surface area of MXenes, further limiting the interaction between oxidative agents and the exposed layers, thereby enhancing their stability and durability. (ii) Electrical conductivity: electrical conductivity is a critical parameter that determines the suitability of materials for various energy-related applications. The hybridization of MOFs with MXenes significantly enhances the electrical conductivity of the resulting composites, making them highly advantageous for such uses. This synergy integrates the exceptional conductivity of MXenes with the porous, tunable architecture of MOFs, yielding materials with outstanding electrochemical performance. MXenes are known for their exceptional metallic conductivity, which can reach up to 20,000 S cm−1 [123,231], a characteristic attributed to their unique layered structure that facilitates high electron mobility through their 2D nature. In contrast, most MOFs exhibit relatively low conductivity, limiting their use in conductive applications. By hybridizing MOFs with MXenes, the composites harness the superior electrical properties of MXenes while overcoming the conductivity limitations of MOFs, thus enabling their use in a broader range of energy storage and conversion technologies. (iii) Mechanical strength: One of the primary advantages of hybridizing MOFs with MXenes is the substantial improvement in the mechanical strength of the resulting composites. Individual MXenes, such as Ti3C2, exhibit outstanding mechanical properties, with tensile strengths reached up to 670 MPa and a Young's modulus in the range of 80 to 100 GPa [232]. These properties are primarily attributed to the layered structure of MXenes, which enables efficient load distribution and deformation under applied stress. Upon hybridization with MOFs, the mechanical properties of the composites are substantially improved. This improvement is due to the effective load transfer between the MXenes and MOFs at their interface. The porous structure of MOFs provides a robust mechanical framework that complements the high tensile strength of MXenes. Furthermore, the interaction between the MOF framework and the conductive MXene layers not only enhances the load-bearing capacity but also mitigates debonding and cracking under mechanical stress, thereby improving the structural integrity and durability of the composite materials. (iv) Thermal stability: thermal stability is a critical factor in determining the performance and safety of materials used in energy applications. The hybridization of MXenes with MOFs enhances thermal stability by improving the interaction within the matrix, which helps to mitigate the thermal degradation of MXenes at elevated temperatures. MOFs offer a protective environment for MXenes, preserving their stability and extending their usability under high-temperature conditions. In addition, MXenes contribute structural reinforcement to the MOF framework. MXenes possess inherent high thermal stability, maintaining their structural integrity up to approximately 800 °C in inert atmospheres [233]. When integrated with MOFs, MXenes provide a resilient framework that effectively distributes thermal stress across the composite. This synergy not only protects the MOF component from thermal degradation but also enhances the overall thermal performance, particularly crucial since many MOFs are prone to loss of structural integrity under high temperatures [234]. (v) Porosity and surface area: One of the primary benefits of integrating MXenes with MOFs is the enhancement of the overall surface area. MOFs naturally possess a high specific surface area due to their porous structures, which arise from the coordination of metal ions and organic linkers. Upon hybridization with MXenes, the resulting composites often exhibit further increases in surface area, attributed to the synergistic effects between the two materials. This increase is primarily driven by the prevention of MOF aggregation and the expansion of available surface sites for gas or liquid adsorption [209].
