Additionally, the presence of MXenes can assist in creating a hierarchical pore structure within the MOF composites. The layered architecture of MXenes improves accessibility to the pores of MOFs, facilitating a more efficient use of the available pore volume. Furthermore, MXenes act as spacers between MOF particles, reducing the tendency for MOF nanoparticles to aggregate, thereby enhancing the structural stability and functional performance of the composite materials. In conclusion, the hybridization of MOFs and MXenes leads to MOF/MXene composites with significantly improved electrochemical properties, such as enhanced capacitive performance, cycling stability, and efficiency. The synergistic effects of this hybridization facilitate superior charge transfer and ion intercalation, thereby boosting energy storage capabilities. By fine-tuning the synthesis parameters, researchers can tailor the electrochemical response of these composites to meet the specific requirements of various applications. 4.3 Interfacial chemistry on MOF/MXene composite for enhanced energy storage performance The interfacial interactions between MOFs and MXenes in composite materials are pivotal for enhancing their energy storage properties. A primary mechanism of these interactions is the improvement in charge transfer. MXenes, with their high electrical conductivity, provide a conductive pathway that facilitates the movement of charge carriers, which is crucial for efficient energy storage. When integrated with MOFs, which typically exhibit lower conductivity, the composite material benefits from enhanced charge transport, improving its overall electrochemical performance [235]. This conductive pathway not only increases electron accessibility but also enhances the composite's overall conductivity. Credited to the aforementioned merits of MOF materials, which are known for their exceptionally high surface areas and tunable porosities, they contribute to an expanded electrode surface area in the composite material. The incorporation of MXenes into the MOF structure increases the composite's overall surface area, creating more electroactive sites and enhancing ion adsorption during charge-discharge cycles. This leads to a significant improvement in the material's specific capacity. Additionally, the synergistic effects resulting from the unique structural features of both components are crucial; while MXenes impart mechanical strength and conductivity, MOFs contribute to the structural integrity and load-bearing capacity of the composite. This synergy results in improved energy densities and enhanced cycling stability, both critical for high-performance energy storage systems. The interface between MOFs and MXenes also involves various chemical interactions, including hydrogen bonding, electrostatic interactions, and coordination bonds between the metal nodes of MOFs and the functional groups on MXenes. These strong interfacial bonds not only help maintain the structural integrity of the composite during cycling but also prevent degradation and performance loss over time, ensuring the preservation of the material's morphology and stable energy storage capabilities. Moreover, the inclusion of MXenes within MOFs enhances ionic transport by creating interconnected 2D MXene layers, shortening ion diffusion paths. This effect is particularly beneficial in supercapacitor applications, where rapid charge and discharge cycles are crucial for performance. The functional groups on the MXene surface further promote ion adsorption and facilitate more efficient electrolyte penetration into the MOF's porous structure, thereby improving ionic conductivity and overall energy storage performance [2,236]. 5 Applications portfolio MXene/MOF composites can be synthesized and functionalized through various approaches, as outlined in previous sections. The fundamental concept revolves around addressing the limitations of each component while fostering synergistic interactions to enhance their intrinsic properties. For example, MXenes exhibit excellent electrical conductivity, while MOFs serve as highly porous scaffolds. Consequently, MXene/MOF hybrids are expected to exhibit not only improved conductivity and porosity but also enhanced physicochemical properties with long-term stability. Due to their multifunctional nature, these MXene/MOF materials have been extensively studied for a wide range of applications, including sensors, water purification, smart textiles, electromagnetic shielding, catalysis, and energy storage/conversion (Table 1 ) [188,224,230,237–265]. Since this review focuses on the integration of MOF and MXene composites for next-generation hybrid energy storage solutions, the following sections will delve into specific examples related to this area. 5.1 Batteries In response to escalating demands for multifunctional electronic devices and clean energy storage solutions, there is a pressing need to advance portable and rechargeable batteries with exceptionally high energy density. Traditional lead-acid batteries are increasingly inadequate for meeting these evolving requirements. Alkali metal-ion batteries, which include LIBs, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), and PIBs, represent pivotal environmentally friendly and sustainable technologies. These batteries play a crucial role in addressing the energy and environmental challenges associated with fossil fuel combustion. MXenes have emerged as highly promising materials due to their ability to mitigate ion diffusion obstacles. Consequently, MXenes are being incorporated to address the limitations of low electronic conductivity and poor stability observed in pure MOFs. This section focuses on MOF/MXene composites as advanced functional electrodes for alkali metal-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs). Recent developments in the application of these materials to battery technologies are systematically summarized in Table 2 [188,189,219,266–286]. The data presented provide a detailed overview of the significant progress made with MOF/MXene composites, emphasizing their advancements in LIBs, SIBs, PIBs, and LSBs. 5.1.1 LIBs LIBs have become predominant in the portable electronics market and exhibit considerable promise for applications in electrifying transportation and grid energy storage sectors. However, advancements in Li-ion battery technology have encountered a saturation point, particularly in terms of performance improvements and cost reduction. Chen et al. [287] demonstrated the fabrication of Ti3C2T x @Co nanocomposite films through electrospinning, incorporating 2D Ti3C2-encapsulated Co nanoparticles derived from Co-MOF precursors. This novel nanocomposite structure, characterized by a unique 1D nanochain morphology, not only preserves high electrochemical activity but also exhibits exceptional electron and ionic conductivity. The combination of Co nanoparticles, possessing favorable conductivity, and MXene, renowned for its high electrochemical reactivity, enhances the electrochemical performance, resulting in elevated capacity and sustained cycling stability. The presence of Ti3C2 flakes contributes to accommodating volume changes during Li+ insertion/extraction, while the electrospinning process effectively prevents self-aggregation of Ti3C2 flakes and aggregation of ZIF-67 nanoparticles. Consequently, this fabrication method yields a larger surface area and increased active sites on the flexible anode. The resultant MXene/Co composite displays outstanding properties, including high reversible capacity, attributable to the synergistic effects of its constituent materials and the tailored fabrication process. Additionally, antimony (Sb) has emerged as a prospective anode material for LIBs due to its elevated theoretical capacity and suitable operational potential. However, challenges associated with notable volume expansion during lithiation and low intrinsic conductivity have hindered its practical utility, resulting in considerable capacity decay and diminished rate capability. To address these challenges, Feng et al. [288] have introduced a combined nanocomposite, designated as MXene-reinforced Sb@C. The synthesis of this material involves the in-situ growth of Sb MOF on a conductive MXene substrate, followed by annealing (Fig. 12 a). The integration of MXene substrate with the carbon layer derived from the MOF forms a continuous and conductive framework that encapsulates Sb nanoparticles. This distinctive architecture serves to alleviate volume expansion, prevent particle aggregation, and augment interfacial charge transfer, consequently leading to a significant enhancement in lithium storage performance compared to conventional Sb@C structures. The resulting nanocomposite exhibits notable characteristics, including high capacity, superior rate capability, and excellent cycling stability, with a capacity retention surpassing 80% over 2000 continuous cycles. Moreover, when utilized as an anode material in Li-ion full batteries paired with LiFePO4 cathodes, the nanocomposite demonstrates a capacity of 168.9 mAh g−1 and achieves a maximum energy density of 381.2 Wh kg−1 based on the cathode mass, highlighting the potential of the MOF@MXene nanocomposite for the advancement of high-performance LIBs. In same context, vanadium diselenide (VSe2) has recently regained attention; however, its application is impeded by synthesis challenges and volume expansion issues. Pan's research group [289] has devised a practical solvothermal method and in situ selenization process to fabricate the VSe2-ZrO2/C/MXene composite from a MXene- MOF hybrid precursor. During synthesis, V2CT x transforms into VSe2/MXene, which firmly attaches to porous carbon derived from UiO-66, aided by ZrO2 via chemical bonding. Remarkably, the VSe2-ZrO2/C/MXene composite exhibits exceptional lithium storage performance, with capacity increasing from 461.2 to 1238.5 mAh g−1 after an initial decline, attributed to a “negative fading” phenomenon (Fig. 12b). Even at a high current density, the composite maintains a high reversible capacity after 1000 cycles, demonstrating superior cycling stability. The potential of the VSe2-ZrO2/C/MXene anode for LIBs has been evaluated through full cell assemblies. On the other hand, conventional synthetic methods for MOFs and MXene-derived materials often involve laborious procedures and significant solvent usage, resulting in elevated costs and environmental harm. Shi et al. [290] introduced a solvent-free approach for producing carbonaceous metal selenide/MXene composites derived from MOFs/MXene, characterized by distinctive nanostructures rich in mesopores and macropores (Fig. 12c). These materials exhibit enhanced Li ion storage properties compared to their solution-based counterparts, with exceptional performance for advanced LIBs storage applications (Fig. 12d), along with an environmentally friendly production process. 5.1.2 LSBs New battery chemistries are emerging with the aim of significantly increasing energy density in a sustainable manner, surpassing existing LIBs. Li-S batteries, theoretically capable of achieving energy densities up to approximately 2600 Wh kg−1, utilize lithium metal anodes and sulfur cathodes. However, practical energy density often falls to a fraction of theoretical values due to the added weight of electrolytes and current collectors. Challenges such as dendrite formation on lithium metal anodes and the complexity of sulfur electrochemistry hinder LSBs development. Despite these challenges, considerable efforts are underway to create safe and sustainable LSBs. Overcoming issues such as polysulfide shuttling and rapid capacity fading during cycling is crucial for their widespread application, particularly in large-scale storage systems. Jiang et al. [239] have developed a porous carbon-decorated, nitrogen-doped MXene nanosheet by in-situ nucleation and pyrolysis of ZIF-67 on ultrathin MXene nanosheets, which are then used to coat commercial polypropylene (PP) separators for stable LSBs. The ZIF-67 nanoparticles uniformly decorate the Ti3C2 nanosheets, acting as spacers to maintain their 2D structure and prevent restacking, while leaving the Ti3C2 surface partially exposed for chemical adsorption due to its Lewis acidic sites. Additionally, the 2-methylimidazole in ZIF-67 serves as a nitrogen source, doping nitrogen heteroatoms into the Ti3C2 nanosheets and enhancing their adsorption capacity, as confirmed by DFT calculations. The combination of nitrogen doping and porous carbon decoration improves the functionality of the N-Ti3C2/C nanosheets coated PP separator (N-Ti3C2/C@PP), effectively preventing polysulfide shuttling and suppressing dendrite growth in lithium anodes. Consequently, LIBs with the N-Ti3C2/C@PP separator exhibit excellent electrochemical performance, including a high reversible capacity of 1330 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, indicating that MOF-derived carbon decoration on nitrogen-doped MXenes is a promising strategy for enhancing the electrochemical performance of LIBs. The 3D MXene@MOF composite has also been utilized as an anode material in lithium-ion batteries. The material consists of 3D porous Ti3C2/NiCo-MOF composites formed through interlayer hydrogen-bond interactions between Ti3C2 and NiCo-MOF nanosheets [237]. The synergistic effects of Ti3C2 MXene and MOF create 3D interconnected porous structures that prevent the self-restacking of both Ti3C2 and MOF flakes while enhancing ion and electron transport. Consequently, the Ti3C2/NiCo-MOF composite electrode exhibits a reversible capacity after 300 cycles, along with excellent rate capability and cycling performance. Recently, lithium-selenium batteries have emerged as a promising alternative to lithium-sulfur batteries due to their high electrical conductivity and comparable volumetric capacity. However, their practical implementation is challenged by the shuttle effect of polyselenides and significant volume fluctuations. To address these issues, a strategy involving the in-situ growth of NH2-MIL101(Fe) (Fe-MOF) on carbon nanotubes (CNT) has been developed to enhance the interconnectivity of MOF particles [291]. This structure is further integrated with Ti3C2T x , forming a novel Fe-MOF-CNT/MX nanoarchitecture through electrostatic assembly. After high-temperature sintering, this nanoarchitecture is used as a host for selenium in batteries, aiming to improve their electrochemical performance. The catalytic benefits of the MOF-CNT/MX nanoarchitecture enhance the cathode's conductivity, ion transport, and overall electrochemical performance of lithium-selenium batteries. The Se cathode with Fe-MOF-CNT/MX nanoarchitecture exhibits remarkable stability, retaining 95.8% capacity after 2000 cycles at a 1 C rate, and 97.9% capacity after 450 cycles at a 10/1 C rate. In addition, Ye et al. [292] developed a novel thin Janus separator (MXene/PP/Cu-TCPP) characterized by anisotropic spatial heterogeneity, particularly with respect to its sulfophilicity on the cathode-facing surface, while preserving the opposing surface as a multifunctional ionic sieve. This asymmetry was achieved through the deposition of nanometer-scale layers of MXene and MOFs on opposite sides of a commercial separator. The highly conductive MXene, enriched with polar surface functional groups, functioned as an expansive sulfur host, effectively confining sulfur and its intermediates on the cathode-facing side, thus enhancing conversion efficiency. Conversely, the non-conductive, porous MOF layer on the anode-facing surface acted as an “ionic sieve,” intercepting polysulfides, promoting uniform lithium deposition, and inhibiting dendritic growth. This strategic design significantly improved the performance of lithium-sulfur batteries, yielding superior cycling stability, a high discharge capacity, and a remarkably low self-discharge shuttle constant of 0.0004 h−1. 5.1.3 Other batteries Aqueous electrolytes are inexpensive, environmentally friendly, and highly safe, making them suitable for large-scale energy storage solutions that address sustainability issues. Flexible and wearable batteries, particularly those using aqueous zinc-ion batteries (AZIBs), meet stringent requirements for affordability, safety, reliable power, and sustainability. The advancement of AZIBs is hindered by several challenges, including the sluggish kinetics of Zn2+ intercalation, which is exacerbated by a pronounced polarization effect, irreversible distortion of the cathode lattice, and side reactions at the zinc anode. A particularly effective approach involves the application of advanced artificial protective layers to stabilize the zinc anode. In this context, Sun et al. [293] have reported the synthesis of Zn/Co co-doped MnO derived from a trimetallic MOF through a one-pot calcination process. The impact of metal ion doping on the crystal structure and electrochemical performance of MnO was thoroughly investigated. It was found that MnO/C doped with 7.5 wt% Co2+ significantly enhances specific capacity and stability. Furthermore, Zn and Co co-doping in MnO/C leads to improved crystallinity and a higher average oxidation state, which boosts the intrinsic electrochemical activity of MnO. This synergistic effect of Zn/Co ions not only enhances the initial capacity of the cathode materials but also mitigates the Jahn-Teller effect, thereby increasing cyclic stability. Additionally, Ti3C2Cl2 was coated on the zinc anode as an interface protective layer, resulting in full AZIBs with improved cycle life and inhibited zinc dendrite growth. The full battery demonstrated a capacity retention rate of more than 98% over 3000 cycles. The application of Ti3C2Cl2 as a protective layer effectively reduces zinc nucleation overpotential, restrains the tip effect, and constructs a dendrite-free anode, significantly enhancing the cycle stability of the full battery. This approach offers a novel direction for the development of high-performance AZIBs. Moreover, a novel microfluidic-assisted 3D printing (M3DP) strategy has been reported for fabricating 3D hierarchical porous Zn-P aerogels based on ultrathin 2D conductive MOF/MXene nanosheets for dendrite-free Zn anodes (Fig. 13 ). Traditional ink direct-writing technology is limited to ink extrusion and cannot directly control the internal structure and functionality of the ink. In contrast, magnetothermal M3DP is an innovative technique that uses microfluidics to modify raw materials in a microfluidic channel and alter their morphology through external conditions during the ink flow process [294]. A symmetric cell with a Zn-P anode paired with an MXene/Cu-THBQ anode demonstrates highly reversible cycling for 1800 h. Additionally, a Zn-organic full battery, combined with a 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl organic cathode riveted on graphene, delivers a high reversible capacity and maintains a long cycle life. MOF/MXene hybrids, with their excellent electron conductivity, ion diffusivity, and consistent nucleation and deposition characteristics, along with numerous surface terminal groups, are emerging as promising substrates for zinc anodes. Their versatile surfaces and robust dispersion in solutions facilitate the formation of various porous structures, supporting research into intercalation, surface terminal modification, and morphological design for zinc anode applications. However, the exploration of MOF/MXene as anode materials is still in its early stages. Understanding the reaction mechanisms between the anode surface and variable-valence metal ions within these hybrids, especially during plating and stripping processes, remains a significant challenge. 5.2 Supercapacitors Among various energy storage devices, supercapacitors are particularly promising due to their high-power density, rapid charge/discharge kinetics, and long cycle life. MXenes, a class of pseudocapacitive materials, are known for their high-rate redox charge storage capabilities, facilitated by surface reactions or rapid intercalative Faradaic reactions. Due to their hydrophilicity and metallic conductivity, MXenes can intercalate various cations, either with or without polarizing the MXene-electrolyte interfaces. In acidic electrolytes, MXenes exhibit notable pseudocapacitive behavior as a result of protonation of their oxy functional groups, leading to changes in the oxidation state of the transition metals. For example, A simple and scalable method for preparing nitrogen-doped Ti3C2T x (N-Ti3C2T x ) electrodes through post-etch annealing in ammonia has been reported, aimed at high-performance supercapacitor applications [295]. This process achieved surface nitrogen concentrations ranging from 1.7% to 20.7% at temperatures between 200 and 700°C. The nitrogen doping, which replaces carbon atoms in the MXene structure, significantly increases the interlayer spacing of Ti3C2T x sheets. Consequently, the N-Ti3C2T x electrodes demonstrated up to a 460% enhancement in gravimetric capacitance compared to undoped Ti3C2T x electrodes under optimal conditions. Interestingly, the incorporation of fast surface redox, and pseudocapacitive, mechanisms allows devices to store significantly more energy than electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) while maintaining rapid charge and discharge capabilities, unlike batteries. However, most pseudocapacitive transition metal oxides struggle with high power capability due to their low electronic and ionic conductivity. Addressing this issue, Gogotsi's research group demonstrated that 2D MXenes can achieve higher rates than traditional EDLCs while providing superior volumetric and areal capacitance compared to carbon, conductive polymers, and transition metal oxides [296]. By employing two innovative MXene electrode architectures to enhance ion accessibility to redox-active sites, they achieved remarkable results: a macroporous Ti3C2T x MXene film demonstrated up to 210 F g−1, outperforming the best carbon supercapacitors. Additionally, MXene hydrogels exhibited a volumetric capacitance of approximately 1500 F cm−3, matching the previously unparalleled performance of RuO2. However, the practical application of MXenes in supercapacitors is severely limited by the restacking of MXene sheets. Although vertically aligned MXene flakes achieved through liquid crystalline alignment displayed thickness-independent capacitance values, their rate performance was suboptimal. In this context, recent advancements in MXene/MOF hybrids and their derived materials for supercapacitors have shown significant potential. The following section will explore specific examples to detail these developments. Moreover, the electrochemical properties of various MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures for supercapacitors are summarized in Table 3 [297–312], with several of them discussed in detail throughout this review. As a proof of concept, Ouyang's research team [313] developed an approach to prevent MXene re-stacking and enhance the electrical conductivity of MOFs. They engineered a highly redox-active NiCo-MOF on a 2D, modulated MXene network characterized by high conductivity to form promising electrode materials. The introduction of MgO nanoparticles serves as a solid spacer, modifying the MXene layers and facilitating their removal in weak acidic conditions, thereby allowing efficient transport of electrolytic ions during charging and discharging processes. The etching process exposes hydroxyl groups on the MXene surface, enabling weak coordination with metal ions and inducing surface defects. These defects generate oxygen vacancies that compensate for the intrinsic limitations of MOFs. Both experimental results and DFT calculations indicate that this strategy significantly enhances the electrochemical properties of the materials. The resultant MXene@NiCo-MOF exhibits a specific capacitance of 2078.1 F g−1 at 1 A g−1. Additionally, a solid-state hybrid supercapacitor constructed with this material achieves a maximum energy density of 40.23 Wh kg−1 at a power density of 1496 W kg−1. The outstanding electrochemical performance in both three-electrode and two-electrode configurations (Fig. 14 ) underscores the potential of this electrode for high-performance energy storage applications. Dai et al. [314] presented a straightforward method to synthesize a 3D porous nanocomposite of CoNiZn-LDH on MXene sheets for use as supercapacitor electrodes. This was achieved by transforming a ZIF-8 in the presence of an inorganic metal salt aqueous solution at ambient temperature. Utilizing MXene as a substrate significantly enhanced the electrical conductivity of the MXene/CoNiZn LDH composite. The resulting 3D honeycomb structure, with its high surface-to-volume ratio, provided efficient ion transport pathways. Consequently, the MXene/LDH composite exhibited a specific capacitance of 2045 F g−1, exceptional rate capability, and stability of 88%. Despite the stability issues of MXene due to oxidation and restacking, which limit its surface area and electrochemical properties, these challenges can be addressed by incorporating a nonconductive material, such as BN sheets, between the MXene layers. Although BN cannot function as a standalone electrode due to its large band gap, combining BN with other 2D materials forms a heterostructure that can facilitate charge transfer. In this approach, a 2D NiCo-MOF is grown on MXene nanosheets, enhancing conductivity and providing abundant redox-active sites [315]. BN serves a dual purpose by preventing restacking and facilitating charge injection toward the NiCo-MOF. The synergistic effects of the 2D materials and the heterostructure, which promotes favorable charge injection dynamics among the MOF, MXene, and BN, lead to enhanced electrochemical performance. The charge transfer mechanisms are analyzed using the distribution of relaxation time technique, which examines complex electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data to differentiate electrode kinetics based on their relaxation time constants. An asymmetric supercapacitor, composed of MOF-MXene-BN//activated carbon, achieves a specific capacity of 798 C g−1, an energy density of 81 Wh kg−1 at 365 W kg−1, and retains 81% of its capacitance over 5000 cycles. The abundant surface termination groups on ultrathin 2D MXene nanosheets facilitate the easy adsorption of cationic ions through electrostatic interactions. Given the electrical conductivity of MXene and the redox activity of MOFs, combining these materials yielded composites with excellent performance in electrochemical energy storage. Liu et al. [305] developed a general method for synthesizing uniform 3D MXene/MOF composites, such as Ti3C2T x /Cu-BTC, Ti3C2T x /Fe-Co-PBA, Ti3C2T x /ZIF-8, and Ti3C2T x /ZIF-67. These 3D MOFs are essential for preventing the aggregation and self-accumulation of MXene nanosheets, thus enhancing the accessibility of MXene to electrolytes and significantly reducing the transport and diffusion distance of electrolyte ions. This combination results in exceptional performance in various applications. Additionally, they created hollow Ti3C2T x /ZIF-67/CoV2O6 composites from Ti3C2T x /ZIF-67, which significantly improved the electrochemical properties while preserving the micro/nanostructures of the original composites. This study paves the way for designing and synthesizing MOF/MXene composites and complex hollow structures with tunable architectures and compositions, suitable for supercapacitors. Building on the promising outcomes of Ni/Co-based MOF/MXene hybrid composites, recent advances include the synthesis of Zn-based ZIF-8 integrated with MXene, the development of Zn-Co MOF hybrids coupled with MXene, and the design of a novel MXene variant (V3C2T x ) functionalized with Ni-BDC ligands. These structures demonstrate potential for enhancing electrochemical performance through tailored active sites and improved structural synergies. The ZIF-8@MXene hybrid electrodes demonstrate notable pseudocapacitive characteristics attributed to faradaic redox processes. These electrodes achieve an impressive specific capacitance of 1279.5 F g−1, maintaining 90% capacitance retention even at a high current density of 30 A g−1. The ZIF-8 framework enhances mechanical stability and structural integrity, while MXene significantly improves electronic conductivity and introduces abundant active edge sites, enabling efficient charge transfer and superior electrochemical performance [230]. On the other hand, the Zn-Co MOFs@MXene hybrid electrode is a composite material comprising polyhedral Zn-Co MOF particles integrated with the layered structure of MXene. This architecture combines the distinct advantages of bimetallic MOFs and MXene, forming a synergistic system. The polyhedral Zn-Co MOFs act as the primary source of redox activity, offering numerous active sites for faradaic reactions due to the dual-metal centers, which facilitate enhanced electron transfer and charge storage. These particles are strategically anchored onto the surface of MXene, ensuring uniform distribution and stability. Additionally, MXene-FeCu MOF hybrid demonstrates superior electrochemical performance compared to its individual components, FeCu MOF and MXene, highlighting its effectiveness as an advanced electrode material [316]. This composite achieves a maximum specific capacity of 460 mAh cm−2 at a current density of 3 mA cm−2, highlighting its remarkable charge storage capability. When incorporated into an asymmetric supercapacitor with activated carbon as the counter electrode, the MXene-FeCu MOF//AC device delivers a specific capacity of 171 mAh cm−2 at 3 mA cm−2. It also exhibits outstanding durability, retaining 89% of its capacity at a high current density of 15 mA cm−2. Additionally, the device achieves impressive energy and power densities, reaching 33.3 Wh kg−1 and 503 W kg−1, respectively. The enhanced performance arises from the synergistic integration of FeCu MOF and MXene. The bimetallic FeCu MOF provides diverse redox-active sites for faradaic reactions, while MXene ensures rapid electron transfer due to its excellent conductivity and extensive surface area, providing efficient charge storage and fast kinetics. By exploiting the synergistic properties of hybrid materials, the integration of electrically conductive MXenes with high-surface-area MOFs has enabled the design of high-performance materials for supercapacitors and batteries. These composites function as high-capacity, recyclable electrode materials, representing a significant advancement toward the development of next-generation energy storage devices. However, the primary challenge in advancing MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures for supercapacitor applications lies in the limited understanding of their underlying reaction mechanisms. Current literature reveals a lack of comprehensive theoretical studies addressing these mechanisms, highlighting an urgent need for in-depth theoretical investigations. Such studies could significantly contribute to advancements across various scientific disciplines, including chemistry, physics, nanotechnology, and engineering. Furthermore, the field of chemical bioengineering presents another promising avenue for the application of MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures, particularly in the development of biocompatible, flexible, and bioelectronic supercapacitor implants, which are critically needed for medical and bioengineering technologies. Therefore, innovations in design strategies, such as the development of all-solid-state supercapacitors and 3D structured materials, can further enhance performance. Moreover, integrating supercapacitors with renewable energy sources to create self-sustaining energy systems presents an exciting avenue for research. By addressing these challenges and pursuing these directions, the supercapacitor field can significantly advance, ultimately leading to improved energy storage solutions for various applications. 6 Summary and outlook MOFs exhibit advantageous properties such as abundant exposed active sites, high specific surface areas, and customizable pore structures and porosity. Despite these benefits, the practical application of some MOFs is hindered by their poor stability and low electrical conductivity. To address these limitations, the combination of MOFs with other advanced materials to create composites has been suggested. In this respect, the MXenes are ideal candidates due to their high conductivity and numerous terminal functional groups. Therefore, the present review examined the synthesis, functionalities, and applications of MOF/MXene-based composites within energy storage systems. The synthesis methods for MOF/MXene-based composites are key, as they significantly influence the properties and potential applications of the final materials (Fig. 15 ). To date, over 30 distinct MXene compositions featuring various structural motifs have been synthesized. This diversity allows for the selection of specific MXene compositions that can be effectively integrated with MOFs for targeted applications. Consequently, it is anticipated that the barriers to utilizing these composites can be overcome in the future through the development of MOF/MXene hybrids. Currently, the exploration of these hybrids is still in its early stages; thus far, only a limited number of MXenes, specifically Ti3C2T x and V2CT x have been investigated for material fabrication across various applications. While numerous MXenes have been reported, very few have been applied in practice. Thus, MXene and MOF-based composites represent promising materials, and their enhanced effectiveness for a broad range of innovative applications is expected to materialize in the future. Despite notable advances, challenges persist in optimizing the synthesis. These include designing MOFs with precise structural control, creating environmentally stable MXenes, effectively integrating the two materials for enhanced performance, and monitoring the real-time changes in composite morphology and composition in order to understand the structure-property relationships. While significant progress has been made in exploring MOF/MXene architectures, specific research challenges still need to be addressed in order to fully harness their capabilities. A significant challenge in the practical application of MXenes is their susceptibility to oxidative degradation, which compromises their intrinsic properties, including electrical conductivity and structural integrity. This oxidation is primarily triggered by the defective sites introduced during the harsh chemical etching process, which act as active sites for oxidative reactions with environmental factors such as water and oxygen. The transformation of high-crystalline MXenes into transition metal oxides, such as TiO2, and amorphous carbon reduces the effectiveness of MXenes in various applications. Therefore, improving the oxidation stability of MXenes is crucial for extending their shelf life. Over the past 14 years, from their initial discovery in 2011 to recent advancements, several strategies have been developed to enhance their stability. These include optimizing synthesis parameters, such as improving the quality of the parent MAX phase, adjusting the type and concentration of acid etchants during chemical etching, and implementing treatment processes that minimize defect generation. Additionally, modifications in storage conditions, such as maintaining an inert atmosphere and replacing aqueous dispersions with organic solvents, have been shown to reduce exposure to oxidative environments, thereby prolonging the stability of MXenes. Furthermore, incorporating polymers can provide protective coatings that enhance the mechanical properties of MXenes while simultaneously improving their resistance to oxidation. These strategies collectively address the oxidation challenge associated with MXene materials, ultimately facilitating their application in areas requiring long-term viability and consistent performance. Despite notable experimental progress, the mechanism behind the oxidative degradation of aqueous MXene dispersions remains incompletely understood. Fully preventing the oxidation of Ti3C2T x and other MXenes is a considerable challenge, particularly when transitioning from laboratory settings to industrial applications for commercial product development. As a result, MXenes have driven the scientific community to explore their oxidation kinetics and mechanisms, alongside the development of innovative strategies to enhance their oxidation stability. As previously mentioned, the harsh chemical etching process used to synthesize MXenes often leads to the formation of defective flakes, which serve as primary sites for oxidation reactions and contribute to the degradation of MXenes. In this context, HF is commonly employed as an etching agent in the fabrication of MXenes; however, its highly corrosive and toxic nature raises serious safety concerns for both human health and the environment. Accidental releases or improper disposal can result in soil and water contamination, posing serious risks to surrounding ecosystems and communities [317]. To address these concerns, researchers are exploring alternative etching methods that eliminate the need for HF. Techniques such as fluoride-free etching, halogen-based methods, and electrochemical processes to minimize environmental impact while maintaining the efficiency of MXene production. Adopting these sustainable methods can reduce reliance on hazardous materials such as HF and advance greener synthesis strategies [2,318–320]. These methods could foster more sustainable MXene production while preserving the essential electrical and chemical properties, marking a key advancement towards eco-friendly manufacturing in materials science. In addition to this, a major challenge is the insufficient understanding of the reaction mechanisms involved, due to the lack of theoretical studies. Further advances in the theoretical research could potentially drive applications across chemical, physical, nano, and engineering technologies. Key areas of focus include controlling the MOF particle size and MXene surface functional groups to prevent aggregation and enhance the nanoarchitecture quality. Effective design strategies for MOF/MXene composites are still emerging, despite the existence of over 20,000 reported MOFs. Additionally, the identification of defects within these complex heterostructures remains incomplete, necessitating further investigation. The MOF/MXene nanoarchitectures should also be adaptable to various pH levels to ensure efficient electrochemical energy conversion across the full pH spectrum and address economic considerations by reducing the use of chemicals and equipment. The selection of MOFs for composites should extend beyond the commonly-used ZIF and MIL series. Additionally, the impact of various MOF morphologies on composite properties warrants exploration. Notably, 2D MOFs could provide larger contact areas when paired with 2D MXenes, potentially improving the charge transfer channels between interfaces. This suggests that 2D/2D MOF/MXene composites hold significant potential for enhanced performance. Although MOF/MXene-based composites are utilized in energy storage and conversion, their storage performance requires enhancement. To increase the charge storage capacity, it is crucial to select appropriate electrolytes and manage the electrode/electrolyte interface effectively. Additionally, the chemical stability of these composites in various electrolyte media must be carefully evaluated. Addressing these challenges through targeted research will enable the development of durable MXene/MOF composites suitable for practical applications, particularly in high-performance materials for supercapacitors and batteries. Abdelkarim Chaouiki has been working an assistant professor for Yeungnam University, Republic of Korea. Prior to the current affiliation, he has been granted Ph.D. diploma from Department of Chemistry at Ibn Tofail University, Morocco. Recently, his research interest has focused on development of advanced surface materials, such as corrosion engineering by organic inhibitor, architecture designing for hybrid materials, geometrical arrangement on reticular chemistry and their computational perspectives to discover the structure-properties relationship of continuum matters as a primary source. Maryam Chafiq has been working an assistant professor for Yeungnam University, Republic of Korea. She received her PhD degree in chemical engineering and technology from Ibn Zohr University, Morocco. Recently, her research has focused on the surface modulation and the relevant characteristics related to structural and functional properties of metallic materials, developing strategies based on porous materials for environmental sustainability applications. Rachid Salghi received his Ph.D. degree from First Mohamed University, Faculty of Sciences, Oujda, Morocco, in 1999, and his Habilitation degree from the University Ibn Zohr, National School of Applied Sciences, Morocco, in 2005. He has been a Full Professor since 2015. His primary research interests include corrosion, density functional theory, and molecular dynamics. Since 2019, he has served as president of the Mediterranean Group of Pesticide Research (MGPR) office (2019–2025). Professor Salghi has been an invited professor at the University of Reims Champagne-Ardenne, Faculty of Sciences, Group of Molecular Spectrometry and Atmospheric Chemistry, France, during the years 2007, 2010, 2013, and 2022. He was also an invited professor at the University of Castilla-La Mancha, Spain, in 2016. He has been awarded two Gold Prizes at the Botgaram International Exposition of Electric Power Technology (BIXPO) in 2017 and 2018. Professor Salghi holds 12 patents. Noureddine Elboughdiri is a full Professor in the Chemical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, Hail University, Saudi Arabia. He received his BSc, Master’s and PhD in Chemical Engineering from the National School of Engineering Gabes, University of Gabes, Tunisia. He joined the Central Laboratory for Analysis and Testing LCAE-Tunisia in 2004 and the SGS Group in 2008 and held different teaching and administrative positions including statistical analysis, academic and industrial accreditation (ABET and NCAAA accreditation/ ISO17025/ ISO 9001) to provide reliable solutions to many of the contemporary problems facing the chemical industries. His research interests are in treating wastewater, Artificial Neural Network, and Aspen Plus simulation. He is selected among the Top 2% World Scientists in the Ranking compiled by Stanford University USA in 2024. Jee-Hyun Kang got her PhD from Univeristy of Cambridge, UK. She has worked as a Professor for Yeungnam University since 2018. Her research delves into the microstructural evolution, phase transformations, and mechanical behavior of advanced materials, with a particular emphasis on optimizing thermal and mechanical processing techniques. Her work has significantly advanced the scientific understanding of materials properties and processing, contributing to the development of high-performance materials for industrial applications. Young Gun Ko has been working for School of Materials Science and Engineering, Yeungnam University, Republic of Korea as a full professor since 2009. Prior to the current affiliation, he worked for Prof. Suresh group at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) where he investigated nanoscale mechanics of light materials as a postdoctoral researcher. He had been granted Bachelor, Master, and Ph.D. diploma from Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH). Recently, he was responsible as a Head of Integrated Materials Chemistry Laboratory for how to improve the electrochemical response of valve metals via surface reforming based on plasma electrolysis. Mohamed Abboud received his MS (2007) and PhD (2011) degrees in organic chemistry from Lorraine University (Nancy, France) under the direction of Prof. Yves Fort. In 2012, he performed a postdoctoral fellow for about three years in Prof. Abdelhamid Sayari group, in the Centre for Catalysis Research and Innovation (CCRI) at University of Ottawa (Ottawa, Canada). He currently works as an associate professor of organic chemistry and nanomaterials in the department of chemistry, college of science, at King Khalid University (Abha, Saudi Arabia). He is a principal investigator at the Catalysis Research Group at King Khalid University. His research focuses on the design, synthesis, and functionalization of organic-mesoporous silica hybrid nanomaterials for main applications in heterogeneous catalysis, heterogeneous chemosensors, and water treatment.

coredata.dc:description: The scalable integration of two-dimensional (2D) lamellar nanomaterials into flexible films opens up innovative possibilities for enhancing the performance and functionality of energy storage devices. However, a significant challenge lies in balancing mechanical strength with optimal energy storage properties. Achieving the necessary flexibility while maintaining high energy density and durability is complex due to the inherent trade-off between these properties. To address this issue and improve the overall performance of such nanomaterial films, researchers are exploring novel approaches such as hybridization with other materials, optimization of layer structures, and innovative fabrication techniques. In this vein, the emergence of hybrid nanomaterials composed of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and 2D MXene sheets offers exciting opportunities in the development of advanced materials for diverse applications. These MOF/MXene hybrid architectures exhibit a unique synergy that combines the exceptional surface area and tunable porosity of MOFs with the high electrical conductivity and mechanical strength of MXenes. This integration leads to the creation of versatile, multifunctional materials with promising capabilities in electrochemical energy storage and conversion, as well as environmental remediation. Hence, the present review delves into the various synthesis techniques employed to produce MOF/MXene hybrids, along with their diverse morphologies and properties, and examines the latest advancements in tailoring these nanoarchitectures for enhanced performance and efficiency. Additionally, the challenges and opportunities for future research are discussed in order to highlight the potential of these hybrid materials in pushing the boundaries of technological innovation across multiple scientific disciplines.
